Index of `iteror` functions by task

Source: vignettes/categories.Rmd
categories.Rmd

Index of [iteror] functions by task

Basic methods

[is.iteror](../reference/is.iteror.html) – Check whether a function has class ‘iteror’. [nextOr](../reference/nextOr.html) – Obtain the next element from an iteror. [iteror](../reference/iteror.html) – Generic function to convert a given object into an iteror.

Consuming / summarizing an iteror

Most of these functions are S3 generic.

[as.character], [as.numeric], [as.logical], [as.list] – Collect all an iteror’s values into a vector. [as.vector] – Collect values into a specified type of vector. [nextOr] – Take the next element from an iteror. [take] – Take some number of elements and return them in a vector. [concat] – Paste an iteror’s values end-to-end in one vector. [consume] – Take all or some of an iteror’s elements and discard them. [count] – Compute all elements, discard them and return their count. [record] – Write an iteror’s elements to a file. [nth] – Compute and discard the first \(n-1\) elements and return the \(n\)th. [quantify] – Consume an iteror and return how many elements were TRUE. [dotproduct] – Sum of products of corresponding elements of two iterors. [reduce] – Combine all of iteror’s values using a binary function, returning the final value. [sum.iteror] – Sum all values of an iteror (i.e. [reduce] using +.) [prod.iteror] – Product of all an iteror’s values (i.e.[reduce] using *.)

Iterate over given data

By convention, in this package functions that construct an iterator have names beginning with “i”.

[iteror.array] – Iterate over an array along given dimensions. [iteror.default] – Iterate over a vector from first to last index. [iteror.data.frame] – Iterate over rows or columns of a data frame. [ienum], [ienumerate] – return the elements of an iterable alongside it index. [irepeat] – Return one value over and over again.

Counting or other mathematically defined processes

[icombinations] – Enumerate all combinations of \(m\) elements of a given vector, with or without replacement. [icount] – Produce an integer sequence starting with 1. [icountn] – Enumerate multiple indices, in either row-major or col-major order. [idiv] – Return a sequence of \(n\) integers that add up to a given total. [igrid] – Produce a sequence over the Cartesian product of the given vectors. [ipermutations] – A sequence containing all permutations of a given vector. [iseq] – Generate arithmetic sequences with specific step size and origin. [iseq_along] – Counting sequence parallel to a given vector.

Random number generation

Random number iterators can be made reproducible by specifying independent=TRUE and specifying a seed value, though this has a performance cost.

[irnbinom], [irnorm], [irpois], [irunif], [isample], [irbinom] – Draw samples from the given distribution. [iRNGStream], [iRNGSubStream] – Create a sequence of seed values so as to make parallel, decorrelated random streams.

Iterators dealing with files or functions

[itabulate] – Evaluate a function over an arithmetic sequence. [ireplay] – reads back values from a data file created with [record] [iread.table] – Reads row-wise from delimited text files. [ireadBin] – Read binary data from file connections. [ireaddouble] – Read numbers from binary connections. [ireadLines] – Read lines from text connections. [ireaddf] – Read rows from several files in parallel (one per column). [record] – Write values from an iterator to a file.

Custom iterators

[iteror.function] – Create an iteror with custom behavior.

Higher order iteror functions

By convention, in this package, functions that transform iterors – creating a new iteror based on one or more underlying ones – begin with i_, with an underscore.

Operating on data within iterators

[i_accum] – Apply a 2-argument function between an iteror’s elements, and return a sequence of partial totals. [i_apply] – Apply a given function to each element. [i_enumerate] – Return a list along with each element. [i_star], [i_starmap], [i_map] – Apply a multiple-argument function to multiple parallel iterators.

Selection, filtering, limiting based on data

[i_keep] – Keep only elements for which an applied criterion function returns TRUE. [i_keepwhile] – Keep elements only until an applied criterion returns FALSE. [i_limit] – Keep only the first \(n\) elements from the given iteror. [i_break] – Return elements only while the given (no-argument) function evaluates to TRUE. [i_mask] – Return elements for which a parallel iterator is TRUE. [i_dedupe] – Discard elements that are identical the immediately preceding element. [i_drop] – Discard elements for which a criterion function returns TRUE. [i_dropwhile] – Discard elements from an iterator until the criterion function evaluates FALSE. [i_unique] – Return only unique elements of an iterator using a hash table. [i_timeout] – Return elements only until the timeout is reached.

Manipulating iterators like sequences (selecting, repeating)

[i_rep] – Repeat each element of an iterable a given number of times. [i_rle] – Compress runs of identical adjacent elements, returning one value and a run length. [i_rleinv] – Inverse transform of [i_rle]. [i_slice] – Return elements based on a starting point ans stride. [i_pad] – After a given iterator ends, return the padding value. [i_recycle] – Record the values emitted by the underlying iterator and replay them. [i_window] – Return adjacent elements from the underlying iteror in a sliding window.

Splitting and combining

[i_chain] – Take all values [i_concat] – Take all values from the list of [i_chunk] – collect \(n\) adjacent [i_tee] – Split an iterator so that teh same values are [i_zip] – Combine corresponding elments of parallel iterators into a list. [i_zip_longest] – [izip] but pad any iterators that end early. [i_roundrobin] – Return one element at a time from each of a series of iterors in rotation.
